awd_titl_txt: COLLABORATIVE PROPOSAL: Legal Questioning of Adolescent Victims
awd_abstract_narration:
In contrast to the expansive and highly influential body of research on children's memory and suggestibility, which has led to clear guidelines about how to elicit accurate testimony from child victims of sexual abuse, little is known about how to question adolescent victims, even though they represent a large proportion of victims who have suffered a range of sexual abuse experiences and are questioned by law enforcement and legal authorities. The lack of guidelines is even more striking for sexually trafficked adolescents, who are often identified as criminal suspects and questioned by police, not trained forensic specialists. How to approach and interview adolescent victims, particularly those who have been trafficked, has never been comprehensively examined. Yet professionals, including interviewers and police, must question these adolescents in a way that elicits clear disclosures from the victims about their experiences in order to intervene, ensure their protection, and prosecute those who commit these heinous crimes. This study will systematically evaluate actual interviews by law enforcement and legal professionals with suspected adolescent victims, including those who have been trafficked. It will determine what types of questioning approaches are used, what approaches are more or less effective at eliciting abuse and trafficking details, and how the questions and victims' responses relate to the outcomes of criminal cases against traffickers. The results of the research will inform scientific models of disclosure patterns in highly vulnerable populations of victims. The results will also impact policy and practice by providing crucial insight into effective questioning approaches with adolescent sexual abuse victims, especially those who have been trafficked, thereby laying the foundation for training protocols on these approaches and long-lasting improvements in practice and policy. 

This research will specifically involve reviewing and coding 340 interview transcripts of adolescent victims, half trafficking victims and half adolescents who have experienced other forms of sexual abuse. For cases that went to trial, transcripts of the victims' testimony, case details and case outcome data will also be collected and coded. Statistical analyses will focus on the types of questions asked and the tone of the questions (for instance, whether the tone is supportive or interrogation-like), as well as characteristics of the victims' responses, such as whether they disclose abuse, the amount of detail they provide, the content of what they report, and their levels of evasiveness. With this extensive coding system, linkages between the question and response categories will be evaluated to determine what kinds of questions are more versus less effective at eliciting specific types of responses from victims and how the questions and responses, directly and interactively, relate to case outcomes.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Commercial sexual exploitation and child sexual abuse are major social problems. A challenge in intervention and treatment is that victimized youth often hesitate to disclose their experiences when interviewed by police, child forensic interviewers, or questioned by attorneys in court. We conducted three studies to identify the ways youthful victims are reluctant and to examine how reluctance relates to the types of questions asked, case characteristics, and the minors involved.


In our first study, we identified 16 ways youth may show reluctance, including several types previously overlooked. We examined a small group of commercially sexually exploited teenagers, most of whom later testified against their exploiters. Over a fourth of their police interview responses were reluctant, compared to only 6% in court. Several factors may explain this difference. First, the most reluctant victims never testified, likely reflecting a refusal to cooperate with the prosecution. Second, different questioning techniques could account for the variation in reluctance. Last, we are currently investigating another possible explanation: victims in court may express reluctance more subtly, for example, by avoiding profanity.


Our second study focused on the same group of teenagers and the relationship between police questioning styles and reluctance. Police often use tactics like maximization, which emphasizes the crime's seriousness and available evidence, and support, aimed at building rapport. Surprisingly, both maximization and support increased reluctance. This suggests that common police questioning methods may backfire with commercially sexually exploited youth, and that support, which in forensic interviews has been found to reduce reluctance, may only make things worse if embedded in coercive interviews.


In the third study, we used the same reluctance measure but focused on a larger group of 10-17 year olds questioned about sexual abuse. Unlike the first study's 26% reluctant responses, only 8% of responses in this group were reluctant. Moreover, 93% had disclosed their abuse before the interview. No age differences in reluctance were found, nor was there a relationship between "don't know" responses and other types of reluctance.  “Don’t know” responses had been used as a measure of reluctance in some prior research.

From these studies, two broad conclusions can be drawn:

The results emphasize the need to understand how victimization is discovered when studying reluctance among exploited and abused youth. High reluctance rates might be more indicative of the discovery context rather than varying between age groups or victim types. Reluctance leads victims to fail to report abuse in the first place, or fail to agree to testify. When victims have disclosed their abuse, or testify in court, they are likely to exhibit less reluctance. This insight is important for interviewers encountering suspected victims, and for researchers studying reluctance. 

Our measure captures the diverse ways in which reluctance is exhibited, particularly among older children and adolescents. It enabled us to test assumptions about the relation between questioning methods and reluctance, and how reluctance changes with age. It also made it possible to test assumptions about how “don’t know” responses should be interpreted. This measure will be valuable in future research, including studies identifying developmental differences among younger children and pre-adolescents.

Our research makes an important contribution to a growing literature addressing the challenges of intervening with adolescents who are victims of commercial sexual exploitation and sexual abuse.
